div.head: Introduction
div.p: This document compiles various concrete use cases implementing the suggested standOff element in order to a) identify possible annotation configurations that may be used as recommended practices for the corresponding phenomena and b) refine the possible constraints that may bear upon it and its sub-elements. It is based on the experience gained in various projects since the initial workshop that took place in January 2014 and which launched the definition of this element, as well as on some ongoing activities that are being pursued in several national projects in France and Germany (among others), in international institutions (EPO) and in the content of several ISO projects (some of which have already been published as standards).
The major conclusions that can be drawn from these use cases are the following:

list.item:
There are only two new elements to add to the TEI space:
standOff: the general container, designed as a mini-TEI document dedicated to gather all annotation related information for a given annotation layer
listAnnotation: a list like element within standOff to allow various types of groupings for stand-off annotations

The content model of annotationBlock must be revised to integrate the multiple usage scenarios that have been identified. Basically we need an alternative (choice) between 2 or 3 possible content models.

div.head: Overview of the standOff proposal
div.note: This section should be conceived as text that would go in the guidelines
div.p: This proposal implements embedded stand-off annotations, i.e. annotations to an existing document that have the following properties:

list.item: Annotations do not alter any part of the document itself, header nor content
There may be as many complementary and competing annotations attached to a given document as wanted
Annotations occur at a precisely determined place in the TEI document organisation, namely as an additional resource, child of TEI or teiCorpus We need a scenario for such a usage
Annotations are conveyed with their specific meta-data, to convey information about origin (software, annotators), specific re-use rights, encoding schemes etc.

div.head: The standOff element
div.p: The standOff element is the container of any group of coherent annotations attached to a TEI document. Its main characteristics are:

list.item: It is attached to the top level of a TEI document by being a member of model.resourceLike
Its content model resembles that of a TEI document by comprising a header (teiHeader), additional resources (model.resourceLike) and a content (one or several listAnnotation elements)

div.p: The actual nature of the standOff can be further specified by means of two attributes:

list.item: type: to indicate the general type of annotations which is being represented
notation: to elicit the specific notation used for the corresponding type of annotation in reference to an external standard or a documented practice.

div.head: The listAnnotation element
div.p: The listAnnotation element is a general container allowing one to structure annotations in various subsections. In this respect, its role is analogous to the one played by div in a general TEI document. Still, div could not be taken up here in order to be able to keep to a very restrained content model.

As an iterative and recursive element, listAnnotation can be typed to indicate the organisational logic of the annotations (e.g. per annotation layer, per annotator, per annotation objects in the case of NER).
The listAnnotation element is also structured like other listXXX elements so that it may start with model.headLike members (e.g. head).

div.head: Updating the annotationBlock element
div.p: The annotationBlock was initially conceived as a construct with a dual role for the inline and stand-off annotation of textual content. For the sake of having it quickly inserted in the TEI guidelines, only a limited range of usages has been documented so far.
In the stand-off annotation proposal, annotationBlock takes a major role as the container for elementary annotations.

div.head: Taking up existing annotations mechanisms from the TEI vocabulary
div.p: The TEI guidelines has a wide variety of elements to implement elementary mechanisms for stand-off annotation. The purpose of this document is to provide more precise guidance as to how to combine them and identify their complementarities. As this stage we can characterised these elements as follows:

list.item: span is a general purpose element to point to a location or a sequence in a document and ideal to cover the general notion of markable in the linguistic annotation literature.
zone, which can be seen as playing a similar role to span in the case of images
interp, which currently has a narrow scope in the TEI guidelines but offers the possibilities to connect annotated passages (inst) with annotation content (ana)

div.head: Aligning with the W3C Web Annotation Data Model (formerly known as Open Annotation model)
Quick presentation of the Web Annotation Data Model
div.p: The Web Annotation Data Model (WADM) articulates around three complementary components:

list.item: Target: that identifies one or several resources about which something is said
Body: that contains what is said about the resource
Annotation: that links one or several targets with 0-n bodies

div.p: This model decouples resources and what is said about them by means of the annotation component. It is highly flexible and powerful since it allows one to associated as many targets with as many bodies as needed.
It is suggested that the Open Annotation model could be implemented as in the standOff construct follows:

item.p: The Target component could be implement with either span for textual targets or zone when pointing to an image.
item.note: See the proposed implementation of annotationBlock: we suggest to introduce a class model.OATarget

item.p: The Body component can be implemented by means of a wide variety of elements depending on the various use cases that we describe here.
item.note: See the proposed implementation of annotationBlock: we suggest to introduce a class model.OABody

item.p: The Annotation component is implemented by means of the interp element complemented with the three following attributes:

list.item: type: to indicate the type of the annotation (e.g. quantity, person, etc.)
inst: points to one or more span elements (possibly in the same annotationBlock when appropriate
ana: points to the actual content of the annotation, depending on the annotation scheme. In simple cases, these could be note (see below) or fs elements.

item.p: Additional elements could probably be used here, but we should provide univocal guidance for such a use case, in order to avoid content model ambiguities and in general too much heterogeneous implementations of the WADM model.
item.note: See the proposed implementation of annotationBlock: we suggest to introduce a class model.OAAnnotation

div.head: Named entity recognition within the WADM model
Introduction
div.p: Named entity recognition is a typical use case for stand-off annotation. It is usually based upon an automatic analysis process of a digital text which produces various hypotheses as to which entities (persons, events, organisations, dates, etc.) are actually mentioned. Given the variety of possible hypotheses, and the quantity of information that a NER module may produce, it does not make sense in putting the resulting annotation inline. Besides, there is a need to record some specific metadata related to the NER process such as the tool that has been used, the parameters given to the tool, etc.

The idea here is to contribute to the definition of a standardised output interface for NER components or online services so that such annotations can actually be re-used, compared, visualised in a systematic way.

div.head: Morphosyntactic annotation
div.p: ISO 24611 (MAF) contains a TEI based serialisation for morpho-syntactic annotations. The underlying model of ISO 24611 is based upon a two level model distinguishing between:

list.item: Tokens: elementary units segmented in the source textual content, and
Word forms: the abstract lexical units that may group together one or several tokens.

div.note: A token can also be associated to more than one word forms, e.g. in French: du, combining de and le.
div.p: In this use case, we make the assumption that the text is tokenized inline by means of w elements as follows, with each token being associated to a unique identifier by means of an xml:id attribute:

text.body:
...
I wanna put up new wallpaper . ...

div.p: In conformance to ISO 24611 (MAF), word forms are represented by span elements, pointing to the corresponding token(s) in the source text (see the note below concerning the use of the proper attributes). The actual analysis of the word form is provided by means of a feature-structure referred to from the span element by means of an ana attribute. The additional corresp attribute allows one to point to the lexical entries equivalent to the word form, when one links the morpho-syntactic annotation to a reference lexicon.
div.note: This representation is not conformant to the WADM model. In some way, the span element combines both roles of target and annotation classes from WADM. The actual body is made of both the feature structure and the lexical entry that are being pointing to.
To be checked: should we use from and to instead of target here.
div.p: The assumption is made here that a lexical resource is available and encoded according the on-going work on ISO 24613 - LMF part 4 (TEI serialisation).

div.head: Reference annotation
div.p: Reference annotation consists in identifying referring expressions in text or discourse and qualify the relation between them (e.g. anaphorical links) or with existing or putative external entities (e.g. in the case of deixis).
The work carried out within the project ISO 24617-9 (RAF) distinguishes to this purpose two types of annotation entities between which various types of links can hold:

list.item: referring expressions: correspond to the actual markables in the text. They may point to text spans, sequences of words (w) or higher level objects resulting from other annotation layers (e.g. word forms is the corpus has been morphosyntactically annotated);
discourse entities: ...

div.head: Parallel annotation of spoken utterances
div.p: The initial model for annotationBlock was conceived to represent the traditional notion of interlinear annotation that one finds, among others, in the field linguistic domain. div.head: Towards a content model for annotationBlock
The baseline
div.p: In the initial proposal, the content model of annotationBlock was limited to a plain and flat class, model.annotation, with the following constraints added to the elements that one would want to use fro annotaiton purposes (whether as source, annotation or body in the WADM):
The major difficulty with this is that there is no way to constraint that one would want to use specific elements as source, annotation or body.
Suggestion has been made (LB, I think) that such a class should better be called model.annotationBlockPart

div.head: Keeping the continuity with the transcription of speech view
div.p: The first constraint bearing upon the content model of annotationBlock is to ensure the continuity with the its initial definition and to allow a stand-off verion of interlinear Partitur annotation.

div.head: An WADM model compliant content model
div.p: In the case of an WADM compliant model, the content model of annotationBlock should be based upon three classes:

list.item: model.OATarget: the class could be pre-filled with such elements as span and surface.

model.OAAnnotation: a mandatory class reference for this annotation profile. The class should contain interp by default and one should be cautious in adding extra element to avoid ambiguous content models when the added element may also appear in the other classes.

div.note: The naming to be change to be more explicit as to the relation to the WADM W3C proposal: model.WADMBody, etc.

div.head: Combining the various possibilities
div.p: In order to differentiate between the different encoding variants we have identified, the annotationBlock element must be associated to a notation attribute Could also be mode which can take one of the following values:

list.item: inSitu: non stand-off usage of annotationBlock as documented in the Transcriptions of speech chapter.
exSitu: equivalent to the inSitu case in stand-off mode
WADM: Open Annotation compliant model (Target, Body, Annotation)

div.note: A simplification of the annotation model may consist in adding inst to annotationBlock, with the semantics that annotationBlock +is+ the annotation level (in the sense of WADM), the target being expressed by the inst and the content of annotationBlock is the body level. From an implementation point of view, this would mean adding annotationBlock to att.interpLike.
